Truck driver given 110-year sentence for accident caused by faulty breaks that killed 4, injured 27: https://twitter.com/i/events/1472270438529077248
Petition asking for commutation or clemency: https://chng.it/4pQLXDFW5F

because I can see the prosecution proving someone knew there was problems then being like, "Well then... you chose to continue operating the truck anyway?"
so whoever that falls on operator or business is whoever would admit it I guess
I think the bigger issue is that he's being charged regardless of the fact that he had a mechanical failure of his vehicle.  And the laws are absurdly outdated.
His options at the time were either crash into a semi parked on the shoulder, which was his only escape route, or continue on with the highway traffic
yeah, mechanical breakdowns can almost always be random, hence why trucks being stranded is always still a sight occationally
And because of the way Colorado's laws are written, the court is required to give him a mandatory minimum sentence per charge.
no one can ever predict something suddenly

yeah, this is why unions and good lawyers are important

I'm looking now.  I believe it was jury.  The judge expresses regret at the sentence, but his hands are tied by Colorado law.

I do know that CDL licencenture expects a driver to do a pre-trip check of all major systems on a tractor trailer. I assume there are things that wouldn't be caught, but also maintenance would HOPEFULLY be logged and performed as needed by an employer

ugh, yeah I read an article about the truck incident, honestly - it was a fully loaded logging truck - and the operator was 23 at the time. No way he's operated long enough to understand all the factors or instinct to be operating especially
in a state with so many mountain passes
I'd say it was foolish of the company to put that on him, but they must have looked the other way so to speak.
I know that even driving the mountains of NH veteran truckers know it's no joke
like toughest days of the job type attitude
also, there are 3 ways to slow a truck like that usually, you have air brakes - that deplete, but then also an engine 'jake brake' and you can use the transmission by downshifting to slow a vehicle.
tractor trailer trans have like 20 gears, it could possibly at least been walked back down to a manageable speed
but under the load of a full lumber stack, could have made that less feasible
btw there is also a retarder
yeah, jake brake here is slang for that
you hear loud weird popping if a truck using one sails by
probably using that + the transmission he probably could have made the crash at least less severe
but he must well know how to use all that in emergency
it's crazy too trailers have "half-gears" between main gears I've heard
i've a bad expirience with broken brake hose during drive
yeah when the one thing that usually works you would totally freak out
eveh i still have a half of brakes it was a real stress
yeah tbf also many people would think emergency brake in a car, but at speed E-brakes are horribly unpredictable
really should only be called the parking brake
actually sucks in an actual emergency
you can use that "handbrake" as a brake, but only at speeds like 10mph or less
if down shifting is still a possibility in a car your best bet is use that by downshifting to a lower speed then use e-brake when you're as slow as you can get
